snippet: The United Nations report, which portrayed the shifting nature of the war as the combat role decreases for coalition troops, said that the death toll this year was especially high for women and children.
abstract: United Nations reports that civilian casualties in Afghanistan have surged 24 percent through first half of 2014, reaching its highest level since 2009; surge is driven by increased ground combat between insurgents and Afghan forces; findings are released just as a Taliban attack unfolds in densely populated center of Kandahar, killing nine people.

byline.original: By AZAM AHMED and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
byline.contributor: Taimoor Shah contributed reporting from Kandahar, Afghanistan, and Ahmad Shakib and Haris Kakar from Kabul.

lead_paragraph: The United Nations report, which portrayed the shifting nature of the war as the combat role decreases for coalition troops, said that the death toll this year was especially high for women and children.

headline.main: Ground Battles in Afghanistan Contribute to Surge in Civilian Casualties, U.N. Says
headline.print_headline: Ground Battles in Afghanistan Contribute to Surge in Civilian Casualties, U.N. Says
